questions.text: A patient with open wound with fracture of both bones of right lower limb came to the emergency. The doctor labelled the injury as 3B according to Gustilo-Anderson Classification. Which of the following would represent the injury?

options.label: A
options.text: Open wound with fracture with wound <1 cm

options.label: B
options.text: Open wound with fracture, 1 to 10 cm wound size, but mild soft tissue injury

options.label: C
options.text: Open wound >10 cm, though soft tissue coverage not required

options.label: D
options.text: Open wound > 10 cm, with extensive injury requiring soft tissue coverage

questions.correct_answer: D. Open wound > 10 cm, with extensive injury requiring soft tissue coverage
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Open wound > 10 cm, with extensive injury requiring soft tissue coverage

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Open wound with fracture with wound < 1cm . This is type 1 of the Gustilo-Anderson classification where the wound is < 1cm in size and is a clear wound.
  • • Option A. Open wound with fracture with wound < 1cm
  • • Option B. Open wound with fracture, 1 to 10 cm wound size, but mild soft tissue injury . This is type 2 of the Gustilo-Anderson classification where the wound size is > 1cm without any extensive soft tissue damage, skin flap or avulsion.
  • • Option B. Open wound with fracture, 1 to 10 cm wound size, but mild soft tissue injury
  • • Option C. Open wound > 10cm, though soft tissue coverage not required . This is the type 3A where there is adequate periosteal coverage present.
  • • Option C. Open wound > 10cm, though soft tissue coverage not required
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The type 3B of the open fracture involves significant periosteal stripping and it requires secondary bone coverage procedure like skin grafting or flap. The wound size is > 10cm in this type.
  • • The type 3B of the open fracture involves significant periosteal stripping and it requires secondary bone coverage procedure like skin grafting or flap.
  • • The wound size is > 10cm in this type.

questions.text: The posterolateral lesion in the head of humerus in cases of recurrent anterior shoulder dislocation is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hill-Sachs lesion

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Bankart’s lesion . In the Bankart’s lesion, the humeral head is forced anteriorly out of the glenoid cavity and tears the fibrocartilaginous labrum from the entire anterior half of the rim of the glenoid cavity, and also the capsule and periosteum from the anterior surface of t the neck of the scapula. The Bankart lesion is the most commonly observed pathological lesion in recurrent subluxation or dislocation of the shoulder.
  • • Option A. Bankart’s lesion
  • • Option C. Reverse Hill-Sachs lesion . Reverse Hill-Sachs defect, also known as a McLaughlin lesion, is defined as an impaction fracture of anteromedial aspect of the humeral head following posterior dislocation of the humerus.
  • • Option C. Reverse Hill-Sachs lesion
  • • Option D. Greater tuberosity avulsion fracture . The greater tuberosity is the attachment site of the supraspinatus, infraspinatus, and teres minor tendons. Isolated fractures of the greater tuberosity are uncommon. Occasionally, a Hill–Sachs lesion in the humeral head may be confused with a fracture of the greater tuberosity.
  • • Option D. Greater tuberosity avulsion fracture
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The posterolateral lesion in the humeral head due to recurrent anterior shoulder dislocation is called as the Hill-Sachs lesion.
  • • The posterolateral lesion in the humeral head due to recurrent anterior shoulder dislocation is called as the Hill-Sachs lesion.

questions.text: Most vascular zone of the bone is:

questions.text: True about Osteoclast is all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Phagocytosis of foreign bodies

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Derived from monocytes . True. Osteoclasts are motile, usually multinucleated cells, derived from promonocytic precursors present in marrow, spleen, and circulating blood, specifically from monocytic/macrophage precursors. They are distinct from osteoblasts and osteocytes, which are mesenchymal in origin.
  • • Option A. Derived from monocytes
  • • Option B. Stimulated by PTH . True. Parathyroid hormone is a major regulator of calcium and phosphate levels in the blood. Parathyroid hormone (PTH) stimulates bone resorption by acting directly on osteoblasts/stromal cells and then indirectly to increase differentiation and function of osteoclasts. When blood calcium levels are low, PTH is released, and it acts indirectly to stimulate osteoclasts (via osteoblasts) to resorb bone, thereby releasing calcium into the bloodstream.
  • • Option B. Stimulated by PTH
  • • Option D. Resorption of bone . True. Osteoclasts are generally regarded as the only cells capable of resorbing bone, creating characteristic, scalloped pits and troughs. The defining function of osteoclasts is to break down bone tissue. They do this by secreting acids (to dissolve the mineral component, hydroxyapatite) and enzymes (like cathepsin K, to break down the organic matrix, primarily collagen).
  • • Option D. Resorption of bone
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Osteoclasts are the multinucleated giant cells that resorbs the bones, formed by the fusion of monocytic cells in the bone marrow. Osteoclasts are stimulated by the parathyroid hormone for the stimulation of bone resorption. They do not function to phagocytose the foreign bodies.
  • • Osteoclasts are the multinucleated giant cells that resorbs the bones, formed by the fusion of monocytic cells in the bone marrow.
  • • Osteoclasts are stimulated by the parathyroid hormone for the stimulation of bone resorption.
  • • They do not function to phagocytose the foreign bodies.

questions.text: Increased Callus or Cartilage formation is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Increased mobilization

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Rigid immobilization . Rigid immobilization is the immobilization of the fractured bone using methods like casting or splinting to prevent movement. While immobilization is necessary for initial stabilization of the fracture, excessive rigidity may hinder callus formation and delay healing.
  • • Option A. Rigid immobilization
  • • Option B. Necrosis of bone ends . Necrosis of bone ends is the death of bone tissue at the fracture site, which can occur due to severe injury or inadequate blood supply. Necrosis typically inhibits callus formation and delays healing.
  • • Option B. Necrosis of bone ends
  • • Option D. Compression plating . Compression plating involves the use of metal plates and screws to stabilize fractured bones, applying compression across the fracture site. Compression plating can promote callus formation by providing mechanical stability and facilitating the alignment of bone fragments.
  • • Option D. Compression plating
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Controlled movement or mobilization at the fracture site can stimulate bone healing and promote the formation of callus tissue, aiding in the repair process.
  • • Controlled movement or mobilization at the fracture site can stimulate bone healing and promote the formation of callus tissue, aiding in the repair process.

questions.text: Marker for bone formation is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Osteocalcin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Tartate resistant acid phosphatase . Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) is an iron-containing enzyme. It is present in bone and cartilage. TRAP is highly expressed in chondroclasts and osteoclasts and, therefore, is used as a specific histochemical marker for these cells. TRAP prompts dephosphorylation of bone matrix phosphoproteins like osteopontin and bone sialoprotein and is important for a normal endochondral bone formation. TRAP deficiency leads to a reduced resorptive activity during endochondral ossification resulting in an osteopetrotic phenotype and shortened long bones.
  • • Option A. Tartate resistant acid phosphatase
  • • Option C. Urinary calcium . Urinary calcium does not correlate with the bone formation or resorption markers as it can provide information about calcium metabolism and bone health but cannot be used as a specific marker.
  • • Option C. Urinary calcium
  • • Option D. Serum nucleotidase . Serum nucleotidase is an enzyme that hydrolyzes nucleotides in the blood serum. It is not directly involved in bone metabolism or specifically associated with bone formation. Serum levels of nucleotidase are strongly correlated with serum alkaline phosphatase levels and have relative specificity for liver disease.
  • • Option D. Serum nucleotidase
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • MARKERS FOR BONE FORMATION
  • • MARKERS FOR BONE FORMATION
  • • Serum bone specific alkaline phosphatase Serum osteocalcin (very important marker) Serum peptide of type I procollagen Type 1 collagen extension peptide (product of type I collagen degradation – more specific)
  • • Serum bone specific alkaline phosphatase
  • • Serum osteocalcin (very important marker)
  • • Serum osteocalcin (very important marker)
  • • Serum peptide of type I procollagen
  • • Type 1 collagen extension peptide (product of type I collagen degradation – more specific)
  • • Osteocalcin or bone Gla protein (BGP) is raised in diseases with increased bone turnover, e.g. Paget's disease, renal osteodystrophy and primary hyperparathyroidism.
  • • Osteocalcin or bone Gla protein (BGP) is raised in diseases with increased bone turnover, e.g. Paget's disease, renal osteodystrophy and primary hyperparathyroidism.
  • • Osteocalcin or bone Gla protein (BGP)
  • • MARKERS OF BONE RESORPTION
  • • MARKERS OF BONE RESORPTION
  • • Urine and serum cross linked N telopeptide Urine and serum cross linked C telopeptide Urine total free deoxypyridinoline Urine hydroxyproline (very important marker) Urine hydroxylysine glycosides Serum tartrate resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) Serum bone sialoprotein
  • • Urine and serum cross linked N telopeptide
  • • Urine and serum cross linked C telopeptide
  • • Urine total free deoxypyridinoline
  • • Urine hydroxyproline (very important marker)
  • • Urine hydroxyproline (very important marker)
  • • Urine hydroxylysine glycosides
  • • Serum tartrate resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP)
  • • Serum bone sialoprotein
  • • Thus, among the given options, Osteocalcin is used as a marker for bone formation as it is produced by the osteoblast cells. Its presence in the blood stream indicated active bone formation.

questions.text: Regarding bone remodelling, all are true except:

options.label: A
options.text: Osteoclastic activity at the compression site

options.label: B
options.text: Osteoclastic activity at the tension site

options.label: C
options.text: Osteoclastic activity and osteoblastic activity are both needed for bone remodelling in cortical and cancellous bones

questions.correct_answer: A. Osteoclastic activity at the compression site
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Osteoclastic activity at the compression site

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Osteoclastic activity at the tension site. True. In bone remodeling, there is osteoclastic activity at the tension site. Osteoclasts help in reshaping the bone in response to mechanical forces. In contrast to compression, sites under tension (pulling forces) often experience bone resorption. For example, in bone growth and remodeling, bone might be resorbed on one side of a bone to allow for appositional growth on the other side, or to reshape bone in response to tensile forces. This is a normal part of how bone adapts and reshapes.
  • • Option B. Osteoclastic activity at the tension site.
  • • Option C. Osteoclastic activity and osteoblastic activity are both needed for bone remodelling in cortical and cancellous bones . True. Bone remodeling involves a balance between bone resorption by osteoclasts and bone formation by osteoblasts. Both activities are essential for maintaining bone strength and structure, regardless of whether the bone is cortical or cancellous. Osteoclasts resorb old bone, creating cavities, and then osteoblasts fill these cavities with new bone.
  • • Option C. Osteoclastic activity and osteoblastic activity are both needed for bone remodelling in cortical and cancellous bones
  • • Option D. Osteoblasts transform into osteocytes. True. Osteoblasts are bone-forming cells responsible for synthesizing new bone tissue. As they become embedded in the bone matrix they produce, they differentiate into osteocytes, which are mature bone cells, and play crucial roles in bone maintenance, mechanosensation, and signaling.
  • • Option D. Osteoblasts transform into osteocytes.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In areas of compression, bone typically responds by increasing its density and strength through osteoblastic activity (bone formation), not by being resorbed by osteoclasts. Thus, the best answer here will be Option A) but this is with respect to modelling not remodelling.
  • ➤ In areas of compression, bone typically responds by increasing its density and strength through osteoblastic activity (bone formation), not by being resorbed by osteoclasts.
  • ➤ Thus, the best answer here will be Option A) but this is with respect to modelling not remodelling.

questions.text: A patient with gunshot wound in tibia presents with comminuted fracture tibia with 2 cm wound. This belongs to what grade of Gustilo-Anderson classification of open fractures?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Grade II

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Grade I . Grade I open fractures involve a clean wound less than 1 cm in size with minimal soft tissue damage. These fractures typically have a low risk of infection.
  • • Option A. Grade I
  • • Option C. Grade IIIA: This grade involves more severe soft-tissue damage or a segmental fracture, which is not described in the question.
  • • Option C. Grade IIIA:
  • • Option D. Grade IIIB . Grade IIIB open fractures also involve significant soft tissue damage, but in addition, they have extensive periosteal stripping, vascular injury requiring repair, or contaminated wounds. These fractures typically require soft tissue coverage procedures like flap reconstruction.
  • • Option D. Grade IIIB
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The given type of injury in the question is comminuted fracture of the tibia but the size and extent of the soft tissue damage falls within the criteria of Grade II injury. So, the described comminuted fracture in this patient will be classified under grade II of the Gustilo-Anderson classification of open fracture.
  • • The given type of injury in the question is comminuted fracture of the tibia but the size and extent of the soft tissue damage falls within the criteria of Grade II injury.
  • • So, the described comminuted fracture in this patient will be classified under grade II of the Gustilo-Anderson classification of open fracture.

questions.text: Internal Fixation is primarily used in all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Compound fractures

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Multiple fractures . Internal fixation is often employed in cases of multiple fractures to realign and stabilize the fractured bones, facilitating the healing process.
  • • Option B. Multiple fractures
  • • Option C. Fractures in elderly patient . Fractures in elderly patients, especially those resulting from osteoporosis or low bone density, may require internal fixation to stabilize the fractured bones and aid in the healing process. In fact, due to the decreased bone density and healing capacity in elderly individuals, internal fixation may be particularly important in these cases.
  • • Option C. Fractures in elderly patient
  • • Option D. Fracture neck of femur . The fracture neck of the femur is a common injury, especially in elderly individuals. Internal fixation is often the primary treatment approach for fractures of the femoral neck, as it helps stabilize the fractured bone and allows for early mobilization, reducing the risk of complications such as avascular necrosis or non-union.
  • • Option D. Fracture neck of femur
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The mainstay of treatment of compound/open fractures is the surgical debridement and external fixation. Internal fixation is done usually in grade I of the open fractures and in the closed fractures.
  • • The mainstay of treatment of compound/open fractures is the surgical debridement and external fixation.
  • • Internal fixation is done usually in grade I of the open fractures and in the closed fractures.

questions.text: Mirel’s criteria is developed for the evaluation of:

options.label: C
options.text: Risk of pathological fracture after metastasis

questions.correct_answer: C. Risk of pathological fracture after metastasis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Risk of pathological fracture after metastasis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Risk of fatigue fracture . Fatigue fractures, also known as stress fractures , occur due to repetitive stress or overuse of bones, leading to microscopic cracks in the bone. Evaluating the risk of fatigue fracture involves assessing various factors related to the individual and the activities they engage in. These factors include high impact activities, poor training techniques, anatomical variations (LLDs, foot arch abnormality, abnormal gait pattern), low bone density, inadequate nutrition, previous history of stress fracture, adolescents, female athletes, long term use of corticosteroids.
  • • Option A. Risk of fatigue fracture
  • • stress fractures
  • • Option B. Severity of osteoporosis . This is evaluated on the basis of the T-score in the dual energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan.
  • • Option B. Severity of osteoporosis
  • • Option D. Severity of neurological deficit . The severity of neurological deficits refers to the extent of impairment or dysfunction of the nervous system, which can vary widely depending on the underlying cause and the specific nerves or regions of the nervous system affected. Evaluating the severity of neurological deficits involves assessing various clinical parameters and objective findings. Various criteria used are Modified Ashworth Scale to evaluate motor function, sensory function testing using various stimuli, deep tendon reflexes, coordination and balance testing, gait observation, vital sign monitoring, neurophysiological testing, imaging and electrophysiological studies.
  • • Option D. Severity of neurological deficit
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Mirel’s criteria is used to evaluate the risk of pathological fracture after metastasis on the basis of presence of pain, and size, location and radiographic appearance of the lesion.
  • • Mirel’s criteria is used to evaluate the risk of pathological fracture after metastasis on the basis of presence of pain, and size, location and radiographic appearance of the lesion.

questions.text: While attending to a victim of RTA, who is otherwise conscious, all the following can be done except:

options.label: A
options.text: Roll the patient making sure there is no movement of the spine on to a hard board

options.label: B
options.text: Strap the patient’s head, thorax & pelvis to a flat hard board in supine position

options.label: C
options.text: Turn the patient to one side

options.label: D
options.text: Assess the patient by asking his name

questions.correct_answer: C. Turn the patient to one side
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Turn the patient to one side

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Roll the patient making sure there is no movement of the spine on to a hard board . True. Neutral anatomical alignment of the entire vertebral column must be maintained while rolling on to the hard board. 4-person log roll maneuver must be used to examine the back and transfer the patient.
  • • Option A. Roll the patient making sure there is no movement of the spine on to a hard board
  • • Option B. Strap the patient’s head, thorax and pelvis to a flat hard board in supine position . True. Strapping of the shoulder, thorax and pelvis, and the head must be done to stabilize the structures and prevent the neck to become the center of rotation of the body.
  • • Option B. Strap the patient’s head, thorax and pelvis to a flat hard board in supine position
  • • Option D. Assess the patient by asking his name . True. On asking the questions, if the patient responds verbally, it means that the airway is intact and the patient is breathing and thinking. This can also assess the level of consciousness of the patient.
  • • Option D. Assess the patient by asking his name
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Turning the patient to one side will be an incorrect maneuver as this can lead to spinal injuries. The victim of RTA, conscious/unconscious, must be least mobilized, and must be moved after properly stabilizing the spine.
  • • Turning the patient to one side will be an incorrect maneuver as this can lead to spinal injuries.
  • • The victim of RTA, conscious/unconscious, must be least mobilized, and must be moved after properly stabilizing the spine.

questions.text: Bankart’s lesion is seen in:
questions.explanation:

There is an impaction fracture of the anteromedial aspect of the humeral head following the posterior dislocation. The radiographs shows loss of normal convexity and presence of a wedge defect in the anteromedial aspect of the humeral head.

questions.text: Which of the following structure passes through the quadrangular space?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Axillary nerve

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Radial nerve . The radial nerve exits the axilla posterior to the brachial artery and then enters the posterior arm compartment through the triangular interval. The triangular interval is bounded by the triceps brachii's long head medially, the teres major superiorly, and the humerus laterally.
  • • Option B. Radial nerve
  • • Option C. Median nerve . The median nerve enters the anterior compartment of the forearm via the cubital fossa. In the forearm, the nerve travels between the two heads of pronator teres, and then descends in a plane between the flexor digitorum profundus and flexor digitorum superficialis muscles.
  • • Option C. Median nerve
  • • Option D. Brachial artery . The brachial artery courses along the ventral surface of the arm and gives rise to multiple smaller branching arteries before reaching the cubital fossa.
  • • Option D. Brachial artery
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Quadrangular space is a passage-way in the posterior axillary region that allows the passage of the axillary nerve and the posterior circumflex humeral vessels.

questions.text: Avulsion of capsulolabral complex is seen from which part of glenoid in bankart’s lesion?

questions.text: Kocher manoeuver is used for:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Shoulder reduction

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Elbow reduction. A traction-counter-traction technique is used under sedation and analgesia cover. The patient is kept in prone with the forearm dangling by the side. A downward traction is applied over the olecranon process while maintaining the elbow flexion. If done in supine position, with the forearm supinated, an axial traction is applied by slightly flexing the elbow. Post-reduction, the elbow is immobilized in 90⁰ flexion with forearm in neutral or pronation, in a long arm splint.
  • • Option B. Elbow reduction.
  • • Option C. Ankle dislocation. Ankle dislocation is reduced with the patient in supine position and the foot at the end of the couch. One person grasps the calf muscle and applies a counter-traction while the other grasps the foot with one hand over the heel and other over the forefoot. For posterior dislocation reduction, slightly plantarflex the foot and distract the heel axially while maintaining the counter-traction. While maintaining the axial distraction, apply a counterforce to the ankle anteriorly, dorsiflex the foot and reposition the ankle joint. For anterior dislocation reduction, first dorsiflex the foot to distract talus and then apply axial traction and push foot backwards while maintaining the counter-traction to the posterior part of the leg. For lateral dislocation reduction, distract the heel axially, move the foot medially and dorsiflex it. Post-reduction, a long leg posterior splint with 90⁰ foot dorsiflexion is applied.
  • • Option C. Ankle dislocation.
  • • Option D. Knee dislocation. This is reduced with the patient in supine with the hip flexed, knee flexed to 120⁰ and internally rotated. A valgus force is applied to the distal thigh.
  • • Option D. Knee dislocation.
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Kocher manoeuvre is used to reduce the shoulder by applying traction in abduction and external rotation, followed by adduction and internal rotation.
  • • Kocher manoeuvre is used to reduce the shoulder by applying traction in abduction and external rotation, followed by adduction and internal rotation.

  • • Option A. Subacromial bursa: The subacromial bursa is a small, fluid-filled sac located between the acromion and the rotator cuff tendons. Its primary function is to reduce friction and provide cushioning during shoulder movement. However, inflammation or irritation of the subacromial bursa, known as subacromial bursitis , can occur due to repetitive overhead activities or trauma. While subacromial bursitis can lead to shoulder pain and discomfort, it is not typically associated with painful arc syndrome.
  • • Option A. Subacromial bursa:
  • • subacromial bursitis
  • • Option B. Subdeltoid bursa : The subdeltoid bursa is a small sac filled with fluid, located between the deltoid muscle and the underlying joint structures of the shoulder. Its function is similar to that of other bursae, providing cushioning and reducing friction during shoulder movement. Inflammation or irritation of the subdeltoid bursa, known as subdeltoid bursitis , can occur due to overuse, trauma, or underlying conditions such as arthritis. However, impingement of the subdeltoid bursa is not typically associated with painful arc syndrome.
  • • Option B. Subdeltoid bursa
  • • subdeltoid bursitis
  • • Option D. Biceps tendon : The biceps tendon is a strong cord-like structure that attaches the biceps muscle to the shoulder and elbow joints. It plays a crucial role in the movement of the shoulder and elbow. Impingement or irritation of the biceps tendon can occur within the shoulder joint, particularly in the region known as the bicipital groove . This can lead to a condition called biceps tendinitis , characterized by pain and inflammation in the front of the shoulder. While biceps tendinitis can cause shoulder pain, it is not typically associated with painful arc syndrome.
  • • Option D. Biceps tendon

ORIF is often considered the treatment of choice for displaced or unstable fractures of the neck of the humerus, particularly in younger, active patients or those with good bone quality. However, in older individuals with poorer bone quality or medical comorbidities, the decision to proceed with surgery must be carefully weighed against the risks.
  • • Option D. Open reduction internal fixation
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The treatment of choice for a 70-year-old patient with humerus neck fracture is conservative with analgesics and a triangular splint.

questions.text: Which of the following movements will be affected if the greater tubercle of the humerus is lost?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Abduction and lateral rotation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Adduction and flexion . Pectoralis major, latissimus dorsi, and teres major are the muscles primarily responsible for shoulder adduction. The main flexors of the shoulder are the anterior deltoid, coracobrachialis, and pectoralis major. These muscles do not have an attachment on the greater tuberosity of the humerus, thus these movements are not affected by the loss of the tuberosity.
  • • Option B. Adduction and flexion
  • • Option C. Adduction and medial rotation . Pectoralis major, latissimus dorsi, and teres major are the muscles primarily responsible for shoulder adduction. The internal rotation muscles are the subscapularis, pectoralis major, latissimus dorsi, teres major, and the anterior aspect of the deltoid. These muscles do not have an attachment on the greater tuberosity of the humerus, thus these movements are not affected by the loss of the tuberosity.
  • • Option C. Adduction and medial rotation
  • • Option D. Flexion and medial rotation . The main flexors of the shoulder are the anterior deltoid, coracobrachialis, and pectoralis major. The internal rotation muscles are the subscapularis, pectoralis major, latissimus dorsi, teres major, and the anterior aspect of the deltoid. These muscles do not have an attachment on the greater tuberosity of the humerus, thus these movements are not affected by the loss of the tuberosity.
  • • Option D. Flexion and medial rotation
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • If the greater tuberosity of the humerus is lost, the movements affected are abduction and lateral rotation of the shoulder because these movements are controlled by the supraspinatus, infraspinatus and teres minor muscles which are attached on the greater tuberosity.
  • • If the greater tuberosity of the humerus is lost, the movements affected are abduction and lateral rotation of the shoulder because these movements are controlled by the supraspinatus, infraspinatus and teres minor muscles which are attached on the greater tuberosity.

questions.text: Fracture neck humerus is common in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Elderly woman

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Young lady . Fracture neck of the humerus can occur in individuals of all ages, including younger individuals. However, it is less common in younger populations compared to elderly individuals. In younger individuals, fractures of the humerus are more likely to occur as a result of high-energy trauma, such as motor vehicle accidents.
  • • Option B. Young lady
  • • Option C. Children . Fracture neck of the humerus is less common in children compared to adults. In pediatric populations, fractures of the humerus are more likely to occur in the shaft of the bone rather than the neck. However, fracture neck of the humerus can still occur in children, especially in cases of significant trauma or in certain medical conditions that affect bone health.
  • • Option C. Children
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • While fracture neck of the humerus can occur in young women and children, it is less common in these populations compared to elderly individuals. Thus, elderly, osteoporotic females are more commonly affected.

questions.text: Wolff’s law states that:

options.label: A
options.text: If a bone is continuously subjected to a particular stress, it will adapt to become stronger to resist that loading.

options.label: B
options.text: Only Diaphysis allows longitudinal growth in childhood.

options.label: C
options.text: Any infection not showing periosteal reaction within 1 week of symptoms can be ruled out to be osteomyelitis.

options.label: D
options.text: Angular deformities will progress till the closure of physis.

questions.correct_answer: A. If a bone is continuously subjected to a particular stress, it will adapt to become stronger to resist that loading.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) If a bone is continuously subjected to a particular stress, it will adapt to become stronger to resist that loading.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Only Diaphysis allows longitudinal growth in childhood . This statement refers to the process of longitudinal growth in bones during childhood, which primarily occurs at the growth plates (epiphyseal plates) located near the ends (epiphyses) of long bones, rather than specifically in the diaphysis (the shaft of a long bone). While it pertains to bone growth, it does not relate to Wolff's law.
  • • Option B. Only Diaphysis allows longitudinal growth in childhood
  • • Option C. Any infection not showing periosteal reaction within 1 week of symptoms can be ruled out to be osteomyelitis . This statement concerns the diagnostic criteria for osteomyelitis. It mentions the presence or absence of periosteal reaction, which is an imaging finding associated with osteomyelitis but not with Wolff's law.
  • • Option C. Any infection not showing periosteal reaction within 1 week of symptoms can be ruled out to be osteomyelitis
  • • Option D. Angular deformities will progress till the closure of physis. This statement refers to angular deformities in bones that occur during growth and development, particularly at the growth plates or physis. It suggests that angular deformities will continue to progress until the growth plates close. This statement does not specifically relate to Wolff's law.
  • • Option D. Angular deformities will progress till the closure of physis.
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Wolff’s law states that if a bone is continuously subjected to a particular stress, it will adapt to that stress to become stronger to resist the loading.
  • • Wolff’s law states that if a bone is continuously subjected to a particular stress, it will adapt to that stress to become stronger to resist the loading.

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely associated with vascular injury?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Fracture shaft humerus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Fracture supracondylar femur . The supracondylar region of the femur is near the knee joint. Fractures in this area can potentially injure the popliteal artery, a major blood vessel behind the knee. Depending on the severity and nature of the fracture, vascular injury is a possibility.
  • • Option A. Fracture supracondylar femur
  • • Option B. Fracture supracondylar humerus . The supracondylar region of the humerus is near the elbow joint. Fractures in this area can potentially injure the brachial artery, a major blood vessel in the arm. Vascular injury is a concern, particularly if the fracture is displaced or involves significant trauma.
  • • Option B. Fracture supracondylar humerus
  • • Option C. Fracture shaft of femur . The femoral shaft does not typically have major blood vessels running directly adjacent to it. Vascular injury in this region is less common compared to fractures near the joints where major blood vessels are located. Fractures of the femoral shaft may cause bleeding from the bone itself or adjacent soft tissues, but direct injury to major blood vessels is less likely.
  • • Option C. Fracture shaft of femur
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Following the fracture of shaft of humerus, vascular injury is least common but the nerve injury is more common and the most commonly injured nerve is the radial nerve.
  • • Following the fracture of shaft of humerus, vascular injury is least common but the nerve injury is more common and the most commonly injured nerve is the radial nerve.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is diagnosed to have irreparable tear of the rotator cuff. Treatment of choice will be:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tendon transfer

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Total shoulder replacement . Total shoulder arthroplasty is contraindicated in cases of irreparable rotator cuff tears because of risk of loosening of the glenoid prosthesis.
  • • Option B. Total shoulder replacement
  • • Option C. Reverse shoulder replacement . Although reverse shoulder arthroplasty reliably improves function and relieves pain in irreparable rotator cuff tears (RCTs), the long-term outcomes in active, high demand patients remains unknown. Non-arthroplasty options represent a challenging but attractive alternative as no long term restrictions are required. Attempted repair has been associated with retear rates exceeding 90%, challenging the utility of repair in this scenario. Several non-arthroplasty treatment options have variable success including biceps tenotomy or tenodesis, subacromial decompression, partial rotator cuff repair, superior capsular reconstruction and tendon transfer. Tendon transfers provide durable and dynamic treatment option for the active high demand patient with an irreparable RCT.
  • • Option C. Reverse shoulder replacement
  • • Option D. Acromioplasty . Acromioplasty is a surgical procedure aimed at removing a portion of the acromion. This procedure is often performed in cases of subacromial impingement syndrome, where the rotator cuff tendons become pinched or irritated beneath the acromion during certain shoulder movements. While acromioplasty can be a part of the surgical management for rotator cuff tears, it is not typically considered the treatment of choice for irreparable tears. Acromioplasty alone does not address the underlying issue of the irreparable tear and may not provide sufficient pain relief or functional improvement in these cases.
  • • Option D. Acromioplasty
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The treatment of choice in a young, active patient with irreparable rotator cuff tear, without glenohumeral joint arthritis is tendon transfer using the latissimus dorsi or pectoralis major tendons.
  • • The treatment of choice in a young, active patient with irreparable rotator cuff tear, without glenohumeral joint arthritis is tendon transfer using the latissimus dorsi or pectoralis major tendons.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy has a history of recurrent dislocation of the right shoulder. On examination, the orthopedician puts the patient in the supine position and abducts his arm to 90° with the bed as the fulcrum and then externally rotates it but the boy does not allow the test to be performed. The test done by the orthopedician is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Apprehension test

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Sulcus test . The sulcus test is used to assess the glenohumeral joint for inferior instability, due to laxity of the superior glenohumeral ligament and coracohumeral ligament. The patient sits upright with their shoulder in neutral. The examiner then pulls the distal part of the humerus in a caudal direction. The test is considered positive when the subacromial space is more than 1cm.
  • • Option B. Sulcus test
  • • Option C. Dugas test . With the patient seated, instruct him to touch the opposite shoulder and bring the elbow to the chest wall. The test is positive if the patient experiences inability to touch the opposite shoulder because of pain. This indicates anterior dislocation of the humeral head.
  • • Option C. Dugas test
  • • Option D. McMurray’s test . McMurray's test is used to determine the presence of a meniscal tear within the knee. Patient Position is supine lying with knee completely flexed. The examiner holds the knee with one hand and palpates the joint line. The other hand holds the sole of the foot, supporting the limb and provides the required movement through range. From a position of maximal flexion, extend the knee with internal rotation (IR) of the tibia and apply a VARUS stress, then return to maximal flexion and extend the knee with external rotation (ER) of the tibia and apply a VALGUS stress. IR of the tibia + Varus stress = lateral meniscus injury; ER of the tibia + Valgus stress = medial meniscus injury.
  • • Option D. McMurray’s test
  • • IR of the tibia + Varus stress = lateral meniscus injury; ER of the tibia + Valgus stress = medial meniscus injury.
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The described test in the question is the apprehension test of the shoulder done to test the anterior shoulder instability, where the patient apprehends from the movement due to the fear of pain.
  • • The described test in the question is the apprehension test of the shoulder done to test the anterior shoulder instability, where the patient apprehends from the movement due to the fear of pain.

Patients should progress as quickly as possible to begin early range of motion exercises to prevent frozen shoulder as tolerated.

questions.text: Which of the following is/are indication of surgical management of fracture shaft humerus? Fracture in elderly Radial nerve involvement after manipulation Pathological fractures Vascular injury Multiple fractures
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 2, 3, 4, 5

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • 1. Fracture in elderly. Fractures of the humeral shaft in elderly individuals may present challenges due to factors such as osteoporosis, decreased bone density, and associated medical conditions. In some cases, especially if the fracture is displaced or unstable, surgical intervention may be necessary to achieve proper alignment and stabilization for optimal healing.
  • • 1.
  • • Fracture in elderly.
  • • 2. Radial nerve involvement after manipulation. The radial nerve travels along the humerus, and fractures of the humeral shaft can potentially injure or compress the radial nerve. If there is evidence of radial nerve involvement, such as weakness or sensory deficits in the distribution of the nerve, surgical exploration and intervention may be required to address the nerve injury, restore function, and prevent long-term disability.
  • • 2.
  • • Radial nerve involvement after manipulation.
  • • ​​​​​​​3. Pathological fractures. Pathological fractures occur as a result of underlying bone pathology, such as tumors or metastatic lesions. These fractures can be associated with significant instability and may not heal properly with conservative management alone. Surgical stabilization of the fracture can help provide structural support, relieve pain, and prevent further complications associated with the underlying pathology.
  • • ​​​​​​​3.
  • • Pathological fractures.
  • • Pathological fractures.
  • • ​​​​​​​4. Vascular injury. While vascular injury is not a direct indication for surgical management of a fracture shaft of the humerus, it is a serious complication that may require surgical intervention. Fractures associated with vascular injury may result in compromised blood flow to the arm, leading to ischemia and tissue damage. Surgical exploration and repair of the vascular injury may be necessary to restore blood flow and prevent complications such as compartment syndrome or limb loss.
  • • ​​​​​​​4.
  • • Vascular injury.
  • • ​​​​​​​5 . Multiple fractures. Fractures of the humeral shaft can occur in isolation or in combination with other fractures, especially in cases of high-energy trauma. Multiple fractures increase the complexity of management and may require surgical intervention to address each fracture adequately. Surgery can help stabilize the fractures, facilitate healing, and restore function to the affected limb.
  • • ​​​​​​​5
  • • Multiple fractures.
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Indications for surgical management of a fracture shaft of the humerus include fractures in elderly individuals, radial nerve involvement after manipulation, pathological fractures, vascular injury, and multiple fractures. Each case should be carefully evaluated, and the decision for surgical intervention should be made based on factors such as the severity of the fracture, associated injuries, patient's overall health, and functional goals. A nerve palsy after a closed manipulation is an indication for exploration + ORIF. A p athological fracture requires ORIF + Grafting + External fixation.
  • • Indications for surgical management of a fracture shaft of the humerus include fractures in elderly individuals, radial nerve involvement after manipulation, pathological fractures, vascular injury, and multiple fractures.
  • • Each case should be carefully evaluated, and the decision for surgical intervention should be made based on factors such as the severity of the fracture, associated injuries, patient's overall health, and functional goals.
  • • A nerve palsy after a closed manipulation is an indication for exploration + ORIF.
  • • A p athological fracture requires ORIF + Grafting + External fixation.

questions.text: The most important cause of non-union of fracture of humeral shaft is:
questions.explanation:

  • • Option B. Compound (open) fracture . These fractures are at higher risk of infection, which can hinder healing. However, infection is not the most important cause of non-union in humeral shaft fractures.
  • • Option B. Compound (open) fracture
  • • Option C. Overriding fracture ends . Overriding occurs when the fractured ends of the bone are displaced and do not align properly. Misalignment can interfere with the healing process, but it is not necessarily the primary cause of non-union.
  • • Option C. Overriding fracture ends
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Distraction can prevent the fractured ends from coming into close contact, which is essential for the formation of callus and subsequent healing. Therefore, distraction at the fracture site is a critical factor contributing to non-union in humeral shaft fractures.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with musculoskeletal complaints. The main concern is to differentiate articular versus non articular origin of pain. Which of the following feature is suggestive of non-articular origin of pain?

options.label: A
options.text: Pain or decreased range of motion on both active and passive movement

options.label: D
options.text: Pain on active movement but not on passive movement

questions.correct_answer: D. Pain on active movement but not on passive movement
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pain on active movement but not on passive movement

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Pain or decreased range of motion on both active and passive movement. In the non-articular type of pain, the pain is present on the active movements only. The limitation of movement or decreased movement is there only during the active movement.
  • • Option A. Pain or decreased range of motion on both active and passive movement.
  • • Option B. Swelling . Swelling may be present in the non-articular origin of pain.
  • • Option B. Swelling
  • • Option C. Crepitation . This is usually absent or unrelated.
  • • Option C. Crepitation
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • In the non-articular origin of pain, there is pain on the active movement and not on passive movement; the ROM is decreased during the active motion; swelling and crepitus may be present or absent.
  • • In the non-articular origin of pain, there is pain on the active movement and not on passive movement; the ROM is decreased during the active motion; swelling and crepitus may be present or absent.

questions.text: A child presents with the following deformity. Most common etiology is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Supracondylar humerus fracture

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Lateral condyle humerus fracture . Non-union of this fracture can lead to cubitus valgus deformity in children.
  • • Option B. Lateral condyle humerus fracture
  • • Option C. Radial head dislocation . Long-term dislocations often result in valgus deformity of the elbow.
  • • Option C. Radial head dislocation
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The given deformity in the question is the gun stock or cubitus varus deformity which is seen as a complication of malunion of supracondylar humerus fracture.
  • • The given deformity in the question is the gun stock or cubitus varus deformity which is seen as a complication of malunion of supracondylar humerus fracture.

questions.text: In Supracondylar fracture of humerus in children, if the radial pulse is absent, what is next line of management?

options.label: B
options.text: Closed reduction of fracture and look for reappearance of pulse

options.label: C
options.text: Closed reduction, above elbow slab plaster and observe

options.label: D
options.text: Open reduction and internal fixation of fracture

questions.correct_answer: B. Closed reduction of fracture and look for reappearance of pulse
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Closed reduction of fracture and look for reappearance of pulse

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Emergency brachial artery exploration. This step is done when the pulse does not return even after reduction of the fracture.
  • • Option A. Emergency brachial artery exploration.
  • • Option C. Closed reduction, above elbow slab plaster, and observe. This option is chosen when the absence of the radial pulse is not immediately concerning for arterial injury, and there is a need to assess the response to conservative management before considering more invasive interventions.
  • • Option C. Closed reduction, above elbow slab plaster, and observe.
  • • Option D. Open reduction and internal fixation of the fracture. This option is typically reserved for cases where closed reduction is not successful, or there are complications such as neurovascular compromise requiring surgical intervention. While open reduction and internal fixation may be necessary in some cases, it is usually not the initial step when the radial pulse is absent unless there are other indications for surgery.
  • • Option D. Open reduction and internal fixation of the fracture.
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • In case of an absent radial pulse in a child with supracondylar humerus fracture, the best line of management is the closed reduction of the fracture and observe for the reappearance of the pulse.
  • • In case of an absent radial pulse in a child with supracondylar humerus fracture, the best line of management is the closed reduction of the fracture and observe for the reappearance of the pulse.

questions.text: All the following are complications of supracondylar fracture of humerus in children, except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Non-union

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Compartment syndrome, Option B. Myositis ossificans, and Option C. Malunion are the common complications seen following supracondylar humerus fracture in children.
  • • Option A. Compartment syndrome, Option B. Myositis ossificans, and Option C. Malunion
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Out of the given options, non-union is not a complication of supracondylar humerus fracture in children. Instead malunion is the most common complication which leads to cubitus varus deformity.
  • • Out of the given options, non-union is not a complication of supracondylar humerus fracture in children.
  • • Instead malunion is the most common complication which leads to cubitus varus deformity.

questions.text: What is seen on X-ray with posterior elbow dislocation?
questions.correct_answer: A. Coronoid process posterior to humerus
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Coronoid process posterior to humerus

questions.text: Microcirculation blockade is a feature of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Compartment syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Sudeck’s deformity . Also known as complex regional pain syndrome , it is a chronic pain condition that typically affects an arm, leg, hand, or foot after an injury. It is characterized by severe pain, swelling, changes in skin colour and temperature, and sometimes motor dysfunction. While vascular changes can occur in Sudeck's dystrophy, microcirculation blockade is not a primary feature of this condition.
  • • Option A. Sudeck’s deformity
  • • complex regional pain syndrome
  • • Option B. Myositis ossificans . Myositis ossificans is a condition where bone tissue forms within muscle tissue, usually as a result of injury or trauma. It can cause pain, swelling, and restricted movement. While myositis ossificans can lead to local tissue changes, it is not primarily associated with microcirculation blockade.
  • • Option B. Myositis ossificans
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Microcirculation blockade is a characteristic feature of the compartment syndrome.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presenting with a cubitus varus deformity and a history of trauma 3 months back. On clinical examination, the 3 bony point relationship of the elbow was preserved. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.correct_answer: D. Malunited supracondylar fracture of humerus
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Malunited supracondylar fracture of humerus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Old unreduced dislocation of elbow. This leads to retraction of triceps muscles and collateral ligaments. Patients presents with a deformed, stiff and painful elbow with difficulty to perform activities of daily living. The clinical picture looks quite similar to malunited supracondylar fracture of the elbow. On presentation, elbow is deformed either in extension or minimal flexion with a limited range of movements. The relationship of three bony point on the posterior aspect of elbow is altered with a prominent olecranon tip at the apex of a scalene upright triangle attached to a shortened and wasted triceps muscle.
  • • Option A. Old unreduced dislocation of elbow.
  • • Option B. Non-union lateral condylar humerus fracture. If left untreated, non-union can lead to pain, instability and cubitus valgus deformity with progressive ulnar nerve palsy. The three-point bony relation is disturbed, with the widening of intercondylar distance and with the migration of lateral epicondyle proximally.
  • • Option B. Non-union lateral condylar humerus fracture.
  • • Option C. Malunited intercondylar fracture of humerus. This also presents with a cubitus valgus deformity and an altered three-point bony relationship with increased intercondylar distance.
  • • Option C. Malunited intercondylar fracture of humerus.
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Cubitus varus deformity with maintained three bony point relationship after 3 months of injury suggests the diagnosis of malunited supracondylar fracture humerus. ​
  • • Cubitus varus deformity with maintained three bony point relationship after 3 months of injury suggests the diagnosis of malunited supracondylar fracture humerus. ​

questions.text: You are an intern in a busy casualty. A patient comes with upper limb fracture. According to priority to be given, which of these should be reviewed urgently by an Orthopedic resident?

options.label: A
options.text: Patient with delayed capillary refill time in fingers of the involved limb

options.label: B
options.text: Having Intra-articular extension of the fracture

options.label: C
options.text: With Abrasion over the fracture of more than 10 cm

questions.correct_answer: A. Patient with delayed capillary refill time in fingers of the involved limb
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Patient with delayed capillary refill time in fingers of the involved limb

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Having intra-articular extension of the fracture. Intra-articular extension means that the fracture extends into a joint. Intra-articular fractures can lead to joint instability, cartilage damage, and potential long-term joint dysfunction if not managed appropriately. While this is significant, it may not be as immediately urgent as compromised blood flow.
  • • Option B. Having intra-articular extension of the fracture.
  • • Option C. With abrasion over the fracture of more than 10 cm . An abrasion over the fracture site indicates soft tissue damage but does not necessarily indicate an immediate threat to the patient's health or limb function. While it may require attention, it is typically not as urgent as issues related to vascular compromise or intra-articular extension.
  • • Option C. With abrasion over the fracture of more than 10 cm
  • • Option D. Having weakness of wrist extensors . Weakness of wrist extensors may indicate nerve injury or dysfunction, such as radial nerve injury. While nerve injuries are important to assess and manage, they generally do not pose an immediate threat to life or limb compared to vascular compromise.
  • • Option D. Having weakness of wrist extensors
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • In a patient presenting with an upper limb fracture in the emergency, the vascular injury should be checked on priority. This can be seen if the patient has a delayed capillary refill time in the fingers of the involved limb.
  • • In a patient presenting with an upper limb fracture in the emergency, the vascular injury should be checked on priority.
  • • This can be seen if the patient has a delayed capillary refill time in the fingers of the involved limb.

questions.text: Supracondylar fracture is usually caused by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hyperextension injury

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Hyperflexion injury, Option B. Axial rotation injury, and Option C. Extension injury are commonly seen mechanisms of injury in the elbow dislocation.
  • • Option A. Hyperflexion injury, Option B. Axial rotation injury, and Option C. Extension injury
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The supracondylar humerus fracture is usually caused by the hyperextension injury of the elbow during fall on an outstretched hand.
  • • The supracondylar humerus fracture is usually caused by the hyperextension injury of the elbow during fall on an outstretched hand.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding fractures of lateral condyle of humerus except:

options.label: A
options.text: Usually seen at 6-10 years of age

options.label: D
options.text: Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is seen

questions.correct_answer: B. Results in Gun stock deformity
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Results in Gun stock deformity

questions.text: A child following fall on outstretched arm, presented with tenderness and crepitus over lateral condyle humerus along with instability of elbow. The condition of the child can cause which of the following complications?
questions.explanation: Ans. D) All of the above

questions.text: Most common complication of lateral condyle humerus fracture is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Non-union

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Malunion. This is seen mostly after the surgical intervention.
  • • Option A. Malunion.
  • • Option C. Volkmann’s ischemic contracture. This is classically associated with supracondylar humerus fracture.
  • • Option C. Volkmann’s ischemic contracture.
  • • Option D. Median nerve injury. This is also associated commonly with the supracondylar humerus fracture.
  • • Option D. Median nerve injury.
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The most common complication of the fracture lateral condyle humerus is the non-union and displacement of the fractured fragments.
  • • The most common complication of the fracture lateral condyle humerus is the non-union and displacement of the fractured fragments.

questions.text: Which fracture requires open reduction in children?

options.label: A
options.text: Fracture of both bones of forearm

questions.correct_answer: D. Lateral condyle fracture of humerus
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lateral condyle fracture of humerus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Fracture of both bones of forearm . In children, these fractures are mostly treated with closed reduction and immobilization. Open reduction is indicated in children > 13 years who are nearing skeletal maturity.
  • • Option A. Fracture of both bones of forearm
  • • Option B. Epiphyseal separation of tibia . In many cases, conservative management is done in epiphyseal separation of tibia. This involves immobilization of the affected limb in a cast or a splint and avoid weight bearing on the affected limb. Open reduction is indicated if the there is significant displacement of the fragments or if the blood supply to the growth plate is compromised.
  • • Option B. Epiphyseal separation of tibia
  • • Option C. Intercondylar fracture of femur . In some cases, particularly for minimally displaced or stable fractures, nonsurgical treatment may be appropriate. This typically involves immobilizing the affected limb with a cast or brace and to avoid weight-bearing activities. If the intercondylar femur fracture is displaced or unstable, surgical intervention may be necessary.
  • • Option C. Intercondylar fracture of femur
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The lateral condyle fracture of humerus is considered as a fracture of necessity which needs to be treated with open reduction and internal fixation because the closed treatment gives unsatisfactory results.
  • • The lateral condyle fracture of humerus is considered as a fracture of necessity which needs to be treated with open reduction and internal fixation because the closed treatment gives unsatisfactory results.

questions.text: Tardy ulnar nerve palsy seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lateral condyle fracture humerus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Medial condyle fracture humerus. In this fracture, the medial nerve is compressed between the apophysis and the distal humerus.
  • • Option A. Medial condyle fracture humerus.
  • • Option C. Supracondylar fracture humerus. The most commonly affected nerve is the anterior interosseous nerve in the supracondylar humerus fracture.
  • • Option C. Supracondylar fracture humerus.
  • • Option D. Fracture shaft of humerus. In this, the radial nerve is most commonly involved.
  • • Option D. Fracture shaft of humerus.
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is seen in lateral condyle humerus fracture.
  • • Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is seen in lateral condyle humerus fracture.

questions.text: Earliest sign of compartment syndrome of leg is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pain on Passive stretch

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Tingling or numbness. Paresthesia, tingling or numbness occur in the late stages.
  • • Option A. Tingling or numbness.
  • • Option D. Pulselessness . It is also the late feature. Presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis.
  • • Option D. Pulselessness
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The first sign of compartment syndrome is the pain and resistance to the passive stretch of the distal-most joint of the extremity.
  • • The first sign of compartment syndrome is the pain and resistance to the passive stretch of the distal-most joint of the extremity.

questions.text: Earliest way to detect development of compartment syndrome by a nurse in a patient with cast is:

options.label: A
options.text: Check radial pulse by displacing the cast

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Decreased response to analgesia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Check radial pulse by displacing the cast. Pulselessness is the late feature to appear in compartment syndrome. It is not a reliable indicator for the presence of the condition.
  • • Option A. Check radial pulse by displacing the cast.
  • • Option C. Change in colour of fingers . This can occur due to vascular insufficiency but is an uncommon entity.
  • • Option C. Change in colour of fingers
  • • Option D. Change in odor . This is not usually observed.
  • • Option D. Change in odor
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The earliest way to detect compartment syndrome in a patient is a decreased response to the analgesics. The patient will complaint of no reduction in the pain symptoms.
  • • The earliest way to detect compartment syndrome in a patient is a decreased response to the analgesics. The patient will complaint of no reduction in the pain symptoms.

questions.text: Compartment syndrome is commonly seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fracture of proximal tibia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Fracture shaft humerus . The risk of compartment syndrome in humeral shaft fractures is relatively lower compared to other fractures.
  • • Option B. Fracture shaft humerus
  • • Option D. Fracture distal end radius . Fractures of the distal end of the radius typically do not lead to compartment syndrome unless there are associated injuries or complications such as significant soft tissue damage, extensive swelling, or vascular compromise.
  • • Option D. Fracture distal end radius
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The proximal tibia fracture is commonly associated with compartment syndrome.
  • • The proximal tibia fracture is commonly associated with compartment syndrome.

questions.text: In Fasciotomy, all of the following are cut except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Muscles

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Skin. In fasciotomy, the surgical incision is made through the skin to access deeper layers of tissue, including the fascia and muscles.
  • • Option A. Skin.
  • • Option B. Superficial fascia . During fasciotomy, the superficial fascia is often incised along with the skin to access the deeper structures, such as the deep fascia and muscles.
  • • Option B. Superficial fascia
  • • Option C. Deep fascia. In fasciotomy, the deep fascia is intentionally cut to release pressure within the affected compartment. By cutting the deep fascia, the surgeon allows for decompression of the compartment and restoration of blood flow to the muscles and other tissues.
  • • Option C. Deep fascia.
  • • Option D. Muscles . Muscles are not typically cut during fasciotomy unless there is necrosis or severe damage within the muscle compartment. The primary goal of fasciotomy is to release pressure within the compartment without causing unnecessary damage to the muscles. By cutting the deep fascia, pressure is relieved, allowing the muscles to expand and restoring circulation.
  • • Option D. Muscles
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • In fasciotomy, all tissues are cut except for the muscles. The skin, superficial fascia, and deep fascia are incised to relieve pressure within the affected muscle compartment and restore blood flow, while the muscles themselves are preserved whenever possible to maintain function and promote healing.
  • • In fasciotomy, all tissues are cut except for the muscles.
  • • The skin, superficial fascia, and deep fascia are incised to relieve pressure within the affected muscle compartment and restore blood flow, while the muscles themselves are preserved whenever possible to maintain function and promote healing.
  • • Ref : OPQR, 6 th edition, page no. 86
  • • Ref
  • • : OPQR, 6 th edition, page no. 86

questions.text: A case of comminuted fracture of tibia presenting with severe pain in the calf on dorsiflexion of the foot. There is also numbness on the sole of foot. Distal pulses are present. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Compartment Syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Rupture of Achilles tendon. Rupture of the Achilles tendon typically presents with sudden, sharp pain in the calf or ankle region. Patients may also report hearing a "pop" or snapping sensation at the time of injury. However, dorsiflexion of the foot usually exacerbates pain in cases of Achilles tendon rupture, rather than alleviating it. Additionally, numbness on the sole of the foot is not a characteristic symptom of Achilles tendon rupture.
  • • Option A. Rupture of Achilles tendon.
  • • Option B. Gastrocnemius and Soleus muscle tear. A tear in these muscles can result from sudden, forceful contraction or overstretching, often during activities such as running or jumping. While a tear in the gastrocnemius or soleus muscles can cause pain in the calf, dorsiflexion of the foot typically exacerbates the pain, rather than relieving it. Numbness on the sole of the foot is not a characteristic symptom of muscle tear, and distal pulses are typically unaffected.
  • • Option B. Gastrocnemius and Soleus muscle tear.
  • • Option D. Tarsal tunnel syndrome. Tarsal tunnel syndrome is a condition caused by compression of the tibial nerve as it passes through the tarsal tunnel, a narrow space on the inside of the ankle. Symptoms may include pain, burning, tingling, or numbness in the sole of the foot, similar to the symptoms described in the scenario. However, tarsal tunnel syndrome is not typically associated with severe pain in the calf on dorsiflexion of the foot. Additionally, a comminuted fracture of the tibia would not directly lead to compression of the tibial nerve within the tarsal tunnel.
  • • Option D. Tarsal tunnel syndrome.
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • In a comminuted tibial fracture presenting with severe calf pain on foot dorsiflexion and numbness in the sole, with present distal pulses, the diagnosis is of compartment syndrome as pain in the area increases with movement in the syndrome while pulses can be present in the early stage.
  • • In a comminuted tibial fracture presenting with severe calf pain on foot dorsiflexion and numbness in the sole, with present distal pulses, the diagnosis is of compartment syndrome as pain in the area increases with movement in the syndrome while pulses can be present in the early stage.
  • • Ref : OPQR, 6 th edition, page no. 86
  • • Ref
  • • : OPQR, 6 th edition, page no. 86

questions.text: ‘Volkmann’s Ischaemic Contracture” mostly involves which muscle in Upper Limb?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Flexor digitorum profundus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Flexor digitorum superficialis, Option B. Pronator teres, and Option D. Flexor pollicis longus muscles are not commonly involved in the volkmann’s ischaemic contracture. They may get involved later in the severe stage of the condition.
  • • Option A. Flexor digitorum superficialis, Option B. Pronator teres, and Option D. Flexor pollicis longus
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The most commonly involved muscle in the Volkmann’s ischaemic contracture is the flexor digitorum profundus, followed by flexor pollicis longus.
  • • Ref : OPQR, 6 th edition, page no. 86
  • • Ref : OPQR, 6 th edition, page no. 86

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented to the clinic after 3 months of traumatic tibial fracture with history of pain and swelling of right leg since 8–10 days. Her skin of that area was shiny, cold and edematous. There was no history of hypertension and diabetes. What is the diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: A. Complex regional pain syndrome I
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Complex regional pain syndrome Type l (CRPS I)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Complex regional pain syndrome II . Also known as causalgia , it is a neurological disorder that produces long-lasting, intense, burning pain. It is caused after injury to the peripheral nerves. The most common site of pain is the brachial plexus. It affects the median nerve more commonly, followed by the tibial trunk of the sciatic nerve. There is pins and needles sensation, hypersensitivity, swelling, stiffness, abnormal sweating and skin colour changes.
  • • Option B. Complex regional pain syndrome II
  • • causalgia
  • • Option C. Fibromyalgia . Fibromyalgia is characterized by chronic, widespread musculoskeletal pain. Fatigue, cognitive disturbance, psychiatric and multiple somatic symptoms often accompany the disorder. There is no evidence of tissue inflammation. It has an unknown etiology. The chief complaint of the patient is widespread musculoskeletal pain, which is bilateral and involves both the upper and lower parts of the body. The pain may be localized initially, commonly in the neck and shoulders. The other cardinal symptom is fatigue, especially when waking up from sleep, but it is also in the mid-afternoon. Minor activities may aggravate the pain and fatigue, though inactivity for a prolonged period also increases the symptoms. There is stiffness on waking up in the morning.
  • • Option C. Fibromyalgia
  • • Option D. Peripheral neuropathy . Symptoms of peripheral neuropathy can range from tingling or numbness to burning pain or paralysis. Other symptoms include muscle weakness, cramps, muscle twitching, loss of muscle and bone, changes in skin, hair, or nails, numbness, loss of balance, loss of pain or sensation, inability to sweat properly, leading to heat intolerance, loss of bladder control, dizziness because of a loss of control over blood pressure etc.
  • • Option D. Peripheral neuropathy
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The described signs and symptoms and history of the patient are suggestive of presence of complex regional pain syndrome I or sudeck’s osteodystrophy which is caused following trauma.
  • • The described signs and symptoms and history of the patient are suggestive of presence of complex regional pain syndrome I or sudeck’s osteodystrophy which is caused following trauma.

questions.text: A person of 60 Years of age is suffering from myositis ossificans progressiva. The usual cause of death will be:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lung disease

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Nutritional deficiency . In the context of myositis ossificans progressiva (MOP), nutritional deficiency is not typically considered the usual cause of death. MOP is a rare genetic disorder characterized by progressive heterotopic ossification, i.e., the abnormal formation of bone in muscles, tendons, and ligaments. While nutritional status may impact overall health, it is not directly linked to the progression or outcome of MOP.
  • • Option A. Nutritional deficiency
  • • Option B. Bed sore . Bed sores, also known as pressure ulcers or decubitus ulcers , occur due to prolonged pressure on the skin, often in individuals who are immobile or bedridden. While bed sores can lead to serious complications, including infection and tissue necrosis, they are not typically considered the usual cause of death in individuals with myositis ossificans progressiva. MOP primarily affects the musculoskeletal system and is not directly related to the development of bed sores.
  • • Option B. Bed sore
  • • pressure ulcers or decubitus ulcers
  • • Option D. Septicemia . In individuals with myositis ossificans progressiva, infections can occur due to various factors, including compromised mobility, skin breakdown, and immune system dysfunction. Septicemia can result from these infections and is a significant risk for individuals with MOP, especially if the infection spreads rapidly throughout the body.
  • • Option D. Septicemia
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The most usual cause of death in the patient with myositis ossificans progressive will be lung disease in the form of severe restrictive chest wall disease.
  • • The most usual cause of death in the patient with myositis ossificans progressive will be lung disease in the form of severe restrictive chest wall disease.
  • • Ref : OPQR, 6 th edition, page no. 89
  • • Ref
  • • : OPQR, 6 th edition, page no. 89

questions.text: What is not true about pulled elbow?

options.label: A
options.text: Occurs due to sudden axial pull on extended elbow

options.label: B
options.text: Forearm is held in pronation and flexion

options.label: C
options.text: Most commonly occurs between 2–5 years of age

options.label: D
options.text: Treatment is quick pronation and flexion of elbow

questions.correct_answer: D. Treatment is quick pronation and flexion of elbow
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Treatment is quick pronation and flexion of elbow

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Occurs due to sudden axial pull on extended elbow . True. Pulled elbow is caused by a sudden axial traction force on the extended elbow that leads to the slip of the annular ligament over the radial head into the radiocapitellar joint.
  • • Option A. Occurs due to sudden axial pull on extended elbow
  • • Option B. Forearm is held in pronation and flexion . True. The child on presentation holds the elbow in slight flexion with forearm pronated. The child apprehends any movement of the affected limb.
  • • Option B. Forearm is held in pronation and flexion
  • • Option C. Most commonly occurs between 2-5 years of age . True. Pulled elbow is commonly seen in children of 1-5 years of age group.
  • • Option C. Most commonly occurs between 2-5 years of age
  • • Option D. Treatment is quick pronation and flexion of elbow . False. The pulled elbow is reduced by flexing the elbow to 90⁰ and rapidly but firmly rotating the forearm into full supination. This is done without anaesthesia, and requires no immobilization post reduction.
  • • Option D. Treatment is quick pronation and flexion of elbow
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The pulled elbow is seen in children aged 1-5 years following an axial traction to the extended elbow. The child presents with the elbow in slight flexion and the forearm in pronation. It is treated by reduction without anesthesia by elbow flexion to 90⁰ followed by rapid forearm supination.
  • • The pulled elbow is seen in children aged 1-5 years following an axial traction to the extended elbow.
  • • The child presents with the elbow in slight flexion and the forearm in pronation.
  • • It is treated by reduction without anesthesia by elbow flexion to 90⁰ followed by rapid forearm supination.

questions.text: X-ray of a 10-year-old child is shown. Which of the following is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Anterior pad of fat sign present
