questions.text: Excision of head of radius in a child should not be done because:

options.label: A
options.text: It produces instability of elbow joint

options.label: B
options.text: It leads to secondary Osteoarthritis of elbow

options.label: C
options.text: It causes subluxation of inferior radio-ulnar joint

questions.correct_answer: C. It causes subluxation of inferior radio-ulnar joint
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It causes subluxation of inferior radio-ulnar joint

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. It produces instability of the elbow joint . The head of the radius plays a crucial role in stabilizing the elbow joint, particularly in certain movements such as rotation of the forearm. Excision of the head of the radius can lead to instability of the elbow joint, impairing its function and potentially causing discomfort or functional limitations. But this can or cannot be seen later in life.
  • • Option A. It produces instability of the elbow joint
  • • Option B. It leads to secondary osteoarthritis of the elbow . The excision of the head of the radius can disrupt the normal biomechanics of the elbow joint, leading to increased stress and wear on the remaining structures. Over time, this can result in secondary osteoarthritis, characterized by the breakdown of cartilage and subsequent pain and stiffness in the joint.
  • • Option B. It leads to secondary osteoarthritis of the elbow
  • • Option D. It causes myositis ossificans . Myositis ossificans is not a direct consequence of excision of the head of the radius. Instead, it is a result of trauma or injury.
  • • Option D. It causes myositis ossificans
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The excision of the radial head in children is avoided because it most commonly causes the subluxation of the inferior radioulnar joint which may lead to the weakness of the affected limb and may affect the daily activities of the child.
  • • The excision of the radial head in children is avoided because it most commonly causes the subluxation of the inferior radioulnar joint which may lead to the weakness of the affected limb and may affect the daily activities of the child.

questions.text: If head of the radius is removed, it will result in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Valgus deformity

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Lengthening of limb. The head of the radius is one of the key structures contributing to the stability and function of the elbow joint. Its removal can lead to alterations in the biomechanics of the joint. However, removing the head of the radius does not directly lead to lengthening of the limb. Limb length is primarily determined by the lengths of the long bones, such as the humerus, radius, and ulna, and alterations in these bones can affect limb length. Removing the head of the radius may cause changes in the mechanics of the elbow joint, but it doesn't directly result in limb lengthening.
  • • Option A. Lengthening of limb.
  • • Option C. Varus deformity. Removal of the head of the radius can disrupt the stability of the elbow joint, leading to changes in alignment. However, it typically results in a valgus deformity rather than a varus deformity.
  • • Option C. Varus deformity.
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • If the head of radius is removed in children, it leads to cubitus valgus deformity of the elbow and elbow instability.
  • • If the head of radius is removed in children, it leads to cubitus valgus deformity of the elbow and elbow instability.

questions.text: In a patient with history of trauma and X-ray showing fracture of proximal part of medial bone of forearm with dislocation, the muscle which may get paralysed will be:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Extensor pollicis longus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Flexor carpi ulnaris . FCU is susceptible to the involvement in the Volkmann’s ischaemic contracture. Since, it is innervated by the ulnar nerve, it is not affected in the monteggia fracture.
  • • Option A. Flexor carpi ulnaris
  • • Option B. Adductor pollicis . This muscle is paralysed in the compression of the deep motor palmar branch of the ulnar nerve. Since the ulnar nerve does not pass through the area of the monteggia fracture, so it is not affected.
  • • Option B. Adductor pollicis
  • • Option D. Opponens pollicis . This muscle is paralyzed in the median nerve injury. Since the median nerve does not pass through the area of monteggia fracture, so it is not affected.
  • • Option D. Opponens pollicis
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The given description of fracture of proximal part of the medial bone of the forearm with dislocation describes the monteggia fracture-dislocation which is the fracture between the proximal third of the ulna and base of olecranon combined with dislocation of the proximal radioulnar joint. In this fracture, the posterior interosseous nerve is damaged which paralyses the extensor pollicis longus muscle, consequently leading to the paralysis of the thumb and finger extension.
  • • The given description of fracture of proximal part of the medial bone of the forearm with dislocation describes the monteggia fracture-dislocation which is the fracture between the proximal third of the ulna and base of olecranon combined with dislocation of the proximal radioulnar joint.
  • • In this fracture, the posterior interosseous nerve is damaged which paralyses the extensor pollicis longus muscle, consequently leading to the paralysis of the thumb and finger extension.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of this fracture?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Monteggia fracture type I

  • • Option B. Side swipe fracture
  • • Option C. Galeazzi fracture . The Galeazzi fracture is a fracture of the middle to distal one-third of the radius associated with dislocation or subluxation of the distal radioulnar joint. Signs of DRUJ disruption on x-ray are widening of the DRUJ on the PA view, ulnar styloid fracture, displacement of the ulna dorsally on the lateral view, and radial shortening greater than 5 mm.
  • • Option C. Galeazzi fracture
  • • Option D. Monteggia fracture type II . Fracture of the proximal or middle third of the ulna with posterior dislocation of the radial head.
  • • Option D. Monteggia fracture type II
  • • Educational objective:

questions.text: Fracture of both bone forearm occurred at same level. Position of the arm in plaster is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mid-prone

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Full supination . For a fracture occurring at the same level in both bones of the forearm, full supination alone may not provide optimal stability or alignment for proper healing. It may also restrict functional movement during the healing process.
  • • Option A. Full supination
  • • Option B. 10-degree supination . A slight degree of supination can help maintain alignment of the fractured bones while also allowing some functional movement in the forearm and wrist. But the most preferred position is the mid-prone position of the forearm as it allows a balanced force distribution across the fractured fragments and the soft tissue and offer greater stability.
  • • Option B. 10-degree supination
  • • Option C. Full pronation . For a fracture occurring at the same level in both bones of the forearm, full pronation alone may not provide adequate stability or alignment for optimal healing.
  • • Option C. Full pronation
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Mid-prone position of the forearm in a plaster allows for a more balanced distribution of forces across the fractured bones and surrounding soft tissues. It may offer greater stability and comfort compared to extreme positions of supination or pronation, especially in cases where the fracture involves both bones of the forearm at the same level.
  • • Mid-prone position of the forearm in a plaster allows for a more balanced distribution of forces across the fractured bones and surrounding soft tissues.
  • • It may offer greater stability and comfort compared to extreme positions of supination or pronation, especially in cases where the fracture involves both bones of the forearm at the same level.

  • • Option B. It is an intra-articular fracture . False. Colles' fracture is typically an extra-articular fracture. It occurs just above the wrist joint and does not involve the joint itself.
  • • Option B. It is an intra-articular fracture
  • • Option C. It may lead to gunstock deformity due to malunion . False. The malunion of the colles fracture is the most common complication, and this leads to dinner fork deformity of the forearm.

It may lead to deformities such as radial deviation of the thumb due to the attachment of the abductor pollicis longus muscle, which is sometimes referred to as the "Hitchhiker's thumb" or "Gamekeeper's thumb" deformity.

questions.text: Which Bone does not form the Wrist joint?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ulna

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Radius . The radius is one of the two forearm bones, and it articulates with the carpal bones of the wrist, specifically with the scaphoid and lunate bones. So, the radius does contribute to forming the wrist joint.
  • • Option A. Radius
  • • Option B. Triquetrum . The triquetrum is one of the carpal bones of the wrist. It articulates with the lunate, pisiform, and hamate bones. Therefore, the triquetrum does participate in forming the wrist joint.
  • • Option B. Triquetrum
  • • Option C. Scaphoid . The scaphoid bone is another carpal bone of the wrist. It is situated on the thumb side of the wrist and articulates with the radius proximally and with other carpal bones distally. The scaphoid indeed contributes to forming the wrist joint.
  • • Option C. Scaphoid
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The wrist joint is formed by an articulation between: Distal end of the radius and the articular disk. Proximal row of the carpal bones (except the pisiform). The ulna does not form the wrist joint.
  • • The wrist joint is formed by an articulation between: Distal end of the radius and the articular disk. Proximal row of the carpal bones (except the pisiform).
  • • The wrist joint is formed by an articulation between:
  • • Distal end of the radius and the articular disk. Proximal row of the carpal bones (except the pisiform).
  • • Distal end of the radius and the articular disk.
  • • Proximal row of the carpal bones (except the pisiform).
  • • The ulna does not form the wrist joint.

questions.text: Most common bone to get fractured in fall on outstretched hand is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lower End Radius (Colle’s fracture)

Explanation:

  • • Option A. Lower end ulna. The lower end of the ulna is not typically the most commonly fractured bone in a fall on an outstretched hand. While fractures of the ulna can occur, they are not as common as fractures involving other bones in this scenario.
  • • Option A. Lower end ulna.
  • • Option C. 5 th metacarpal. Fractures of the 5th metacarpal bone, particularly in the region of the neck, are commonly known as boxer's fractures. These fractures can occur when a person punches an object with a closed fist. While fractures of the metacarpal bones can result from falls, they are not as common in this context compared to fractures of the distal radius.
  • • Option C. 5 th metacarpal.
  • • boxer's fractures.
  • • Option D. Capitate. The capitate is one of the carpal bones located in the wrist. Fractures of the capitate bone are less common than fractures involving the distal radius, particularly in a fall on an outstretched hand scenario.
  • • Option D. Capitate.
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Given the context of a fall on an outstretched hand, Lower End Radius (Colle’s fracture), is the most appropriate answer as it corresponds to the commonly observed injury pattern in such cases.

When there's trauma or injury to a muscle, there might be bleeding leading to the formation of a hematoma. In myositis ossificans, it is believed that osteoblasts from nearby bone or from the muscle itself migrate to the hematoma and contribute to the formation of new bone.
  • • Option A. Migration of osteoblasts to haematoma
  • • Option B. New bone formation . This is a characteristic feature of myositis ossificans.
  • • Option B. New bone formation
  • • Option C. Ossification of subperiosteal haematoma . In myositis ossificans, it is possible for the hematoma to undergo ossification, leading to the formation of bone in the muscle tissue.

questions.text: A young man had a fall on his outstretched hand, presented to the hospital with pain on the radial side of wrist and swelling in the anatomical snuff box. X-ray showed the following findings. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Scaphoid fracture

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Trans scaphoid-perilunate disruption fracture . It is caused by high-energy trauma and result from an axial load applied to the outstretched hand. Load application to the fixed pronated forearm leads to hyperextension, intercarpal supination, and ulnar deviation of the wrist. There is pain and swelling over the hand and wrist, and gross deformity of the wrist can be noted. Evidence of median nerve injury is common. Acute carpal tunnel syndrome is observed. The key to diagnosis is recognizing the dislocated head of the capitate to the lunate in a radiograph.
  • • Option B. Trans scaphoid-perilunate disruption fracture
  • • Option C. Hook of hamate fracture . Hook of hamate fractures are rare, often missed, injuries generally as a result of a direct blow to the hamate bone, most commonly seen in athletes. Symptoms include ulnar-sided wrist pain, hypothenar pain and pain with activities requiring tight grip. PA view shows absence of eye sign or cortical ring which is normally produced by an intact hook.
  • • Option C. Hook of hamate fracture
  • • Option D. Distal radius fracture . These fractures most frequently occur as a result of fall on the outstretched hand (FOOSH) injuries. In the elderly, they are often the result of low-energy falls from a standing or seated position. They are often comminuted and intra-articular fractures. Patients with distal radial fractures will often complain of post-traumatic distal upper extremity pain.
  • • Option D. Distal radius fracture
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The given x-ray image, clinical findings and the history of the patient are suggestive of scaphoid fracture.
  • • The given x-ray image, clinical findings and the history of the patient are suggestive of scaphoid fracture.

  • • Option A. Pronator teres.
  • • Option B. Brachioradialis . It originates from the lateral supracondylar ridge of the humerus and inserts onto the radius. Brachioradialis has a vascularized blood supply and can potentially be used as a source of vascularized muscle-pedicle graft in the treatment of non-union of the scaphoid bone.
  • • Option B. Brachioradialis
  • • Option D. Extensor pollicis longus . It originates from the middle third of the ulna and inserts onto the distal phalanx of the thumb. While extensor pollicis longus has a vascularized blood supply, it is not commonly used for vascularized muscle-pedicle grafts in the treatment of non-union of the scaphoid bone.
  • • Option D. Extensor pollicis longus
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Out of the given options, the most feasible vascularized muscle-pedicle graft for the treatment of the non-union of scaphoid fracture is the pronator quadratus due to its close location and good vascularization.

questions.text: A patient presents with wrist trauma. On investigations, patient is diagnosed to have a sprained wrist without any evidence of fracture. There is tenderness in anatomical snuffbox. Which ligament is commonly involved?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Scapholunate ligament

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Radial collateral ligament. Radial collateral ligament injuries of the thumb metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint, associated with partial or complete tear of the ligament, are uncommon injuries of the thumb. Acute collateral ligament injuries may be seen during sporting activities. Mechanism of injury is radially-directed force causing hyper-abduction moment at the thumb MCP. Radial-sided MCP pain is the most common complaint for RCL tear. Tenderness is present at site of ligament injury (proximal for RCL).
  • • Option B. Radial collateral ligament.
  • • Option C. Lunotriquetral ligament . Lunotriquetral Ligament Injuries are rare traumatic injuries to the wrist that can lead to volar intercalated segment instability (VISI) which is caused by a combination of injury to the lunotriquetral ligament and the dorsal radiocarpal ligament. It is less common than Scapholunate ligament injury. This injury occurs with wrist hyperextension or extension and radial deviation. The patient experiences ulnar sided pain that is worse with pronation and ulnar deviation (power grip).
  • • Option C. Lunotriquetral ligament
  • • Option D. Ulnar collateral ligament . Ulnar collateral ligament injury of the thumb, also known as skier's thumb or gamekeeper's thumb , is an injury of the ulnar collateral ligament of the first metacarpophalangeal joint. Injuries are often sustained by activities or traumatic events that force the thumb into extreme abduction or hyperextension. The patient complains of discomfort localized to the first metacarpophalangeal joint area. There may be accompanying swelling near or at the thumb base.
  • • Option D. Ulnar collateral ligament
  • • skier's thumb
  • • gamekeeper's thumb
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The given clinical presentation of the patient of history of traumatic wrist sprain and tenderness in anatomical snuff box are suggestive of scapholunate ligament injury.

questions.text: Garden spade deformity is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Smith’s fracture

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Barton’s fracture . Barton's fracture is a type of distal radius fracture where the fracture line extends into the wrist joint. This fracture typically involves displacement of the fractured fragment, which can lead to significant deformity. Barton's fractures are more commonly characterized by volar or dorsal displacement of the distal fragment of the radius, rather than resembling the shape of a garden spade.
  • • Option A. Barton’s fracture
  • • Option B. Colles fracture . This involves the fracture of the lower end of radius at its cortico-cancellous junction. It may present as a dinner fork deformity if the fracture is malunited.
  • • Option B. Colles fracture
  • • Option D. Bennet’s fracture . Bennett's fracture involves the base of the first metacarpal bone, near the carpometacarpal joint of the thumb. This fracture is an intra-articular fracture. It can lead to deformity and instability of the thumb, and is often characterized by subluxation or dislocation of the first metacarpal base, leading to a loss of thumb function and stability.
  • • Option D. Bennet’s fracture

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Open reduction and fixation . Surgery may be considered when conservative management is not enough to reduce a Smith fracture. The choice of surgical approach depends on the injury's extent, degree of displacement, patient's age, occupation, and overall health. The first option is closed reduction with percutaneous pinning (CRPP). The second option is external fixation. The third option is ORIF.
  • • Option A. Open reduction and fixation
  • • Option B. Plaster cast with forearm in pronation . The cast applied in a long arm/above elbow cast with the forearm kept in supination and not pronation.
  • • Option B. Plaster cast with forearm in pronation
  • • Option C. Closed reduction with below-elbow cast . The cast applied for closed reduction is above elbow and not below elbow.
  • • Option C. Closed reduction with below-elbow cast

questions.text: Stellate ganglion block is useful in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sudeck’s osteodystrophy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Compound palmar ganglion . Compound palmar ganglion, also known as chronic flexor tenosynovitis , is a condition involving the flexor tendons around the wrist, above and below the flexor retinaculum. Most common etiologies are tuberculosis and rheumatoid arthritis. Treatment of choice for such conditions include complete excision of the mass along with the radical synovectomy of the wrist joint and associated flexor tendon sheaths followed by anti-tubercular medications. With early diagnosis and treatment good recovery can be achieved.
  • • Option B. Compound palmar ganglion
  • • chronic flexor tenosynovitis
  • • Option C. Tenosynovitis . Infectious tenosynovitis treatment can include broad-spectrum antibiotics such as vancomycin at 15 to 20 mg/kg/dose every 8 to 12 hours with a third-generation cephalosporin at 1 to 2 g IV every 24 hours. Non-infectious tenosynovitis is treated conservatively with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as naproxen. Additional first-line treatment may consist of activity modification, splinting, and glucocorticoid injections. Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) such as glucocorticoids may be additionally helpful in patients in patients who fail a trial of NSAIDs. Surgical intervention may become necessary after 3 to 6 months of progression despite conservative therapy. Surgical intervention may involve the decompression of affected tendons as well as debridement of inflammatory tissues.
  • • Option C. Tenosynovitis
  • • Option D. Osteoarthritis of first CMC joint . Activity modification, or using splints, slings, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and cortisol injections are all examples of conservative treatment. Surgical options include osteotomy, trapezial excision, ligament reconstruction with or without tendon interposition, and various prosthetic interpositional implants with or without trapezial excision.
  • • Option D. Osteoarthritis of first CMC joint
